variant.question: The principle of damage tolerance in structural design of an aircraft is based on the

options.text: capability to withstand a certain amount of damage to structural parts until the damage is detected during an inspection.
assumption that the structure has more than one load path.
replacement of parts after a given number of cycles or hours of use.
assumption that there is no need to inspect the structure.

variant.question: In the context of aviation and loadings on an aircraft`s structure..

options.text: strain is a measure of the deformation of a loaded structure.
stress of a material is often known as the Young`s modulus of elasticity.
stress is the ratio of the change in length to the original length of a loaded structure.
the definitions of stress and strain are interchangeable.

variant.question: Which statement is correct? If the aircraft fuselage consists of formers, stringers or longerons and stressed skin, the fuselage is a..
With regard to an aircraft fuselage, a FAIL SAFE structure is one:

options.text: in which the load is carried by other components if a part of the structure fails.
that is only used for a limited time.

variant.question: With regard to an aircraft fuselage, a FAIL SAFE structure is one:

options.text: in which the adjacent structural members can carry the load for a limited time.
in which the adjacent structural members can carry the load for an unlimited time.

variant.question: According EASA CS the worst effect of a CATASTROPHIC FAILURE on the occupants of an aeroplane excluding flight crew could be

options.text: serious or fatal injury to a small number of passengers or cabin crew.

variant.question: In straight and level flight the loads on a cantilever wing with a torsion box are:

options.text: compression in the upper skin, tension in the lower skin.
compression in both the upper and the lower skin.
tension in the upper skin, compression in the lower skin.
tension in both the upper and the lower skin.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 021-31.
Refer to the attached annex depicting various types of fuselage cross-sections. Place these cross-sections in order of DECREASING structural suitability for a pressurized cabin.
In flight, a cantilever wing of an aeroplane containing fuel is subjected to vertical loads that produce a bending moment that is

options.text: equal to the zero-fuel weight multiplied by the span.
equal to half the weight of the aeroplane multiplied by the semi-span.

1) On some aeroplanes the cockpit windows have an additional speed restriction, related to bird impact, when window heating is inoperative.
2) Cockpit side windows are usually defogged only.

The part of the aircraft’s fuselage which gives it its aerodynamic shape is the:
A typical wing structure consists primarily of

options.text: a front and rear main spar with ribs and stringers.
ribs only to give optimum and cost effective simple construction.
a front and rear main spar.

variant.question: What is the reason for heating flight deck windows?

options.text: To protect the windows against bird strike damage and ice formation.
To de-mist the interior of the window if normal de-mist does not function correctly.
To protect the windows against ice formation.
To protect the windows against bird strike damage.

variant.question:
The bending loads on a cantilever wing due to lift are carried by the: 
1. Upper skin surface. 
2. Lower skin surface. 
3. Wing root fairing. 
4. Spar or spars. 
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

Significant torsion effects on a wing structure during flight can be caused by:
The purpose of a cockpit eye reference indicator is...

options.text: To have a correct vertical and horizontal field of view only moving eyes.
To have a correct vertical and horizontal field of view with minimal head movement.
To have a correct vertical and horizontal field of view with full head movement.
To have the correct horizontal field of view.

variant.question: Which statement about the wing structure is correct?

options.text: The torsion box of a wing includes the wing spars and skin.
A wing main spar consists of a web with stringers.
The slats are a part of the wing torsion box.
A wing structure is a semi-monocoque structure consisting of skin and frames.

variant.question: The highest load on the torsion link in a bogie gear is experienced:

options.text: while turning on the ground with a small radius.
when braking with an inoperative anti-skid system.
on touchdown with a strong crosswind.

variant.question: The purpose of stringers, used in fuselage construction, is to:

options.text: assist the skin absorb longitudinal compressive loads.
carry the loads due to pressurisation and convert them into tensile stress.
provide attachment for the sound and thermal insulation.

variant.question: When the wing skin is not able to carry loads, the structural elements of the wing, which carry the bending moment, are
Engine compartment decking and firewalls are typically manufactured from:

options.text: composite materials such as carbon, kevlar and fibre glass.

variant.question: What is the main purpose of flight-deck windshield heating?

options.text: To heat the vinyl and increase its impact resistance.
To heat the glass and increase its impact resistance.
To prevent the glass from fogging up.
To keep the cabin temperature at a comfortable level.

variant.question: The fuselage structure of a modern pressurised transport aeroplane is an example of a...
A framework of truss type fuselage is used in

options.text: heavy wide bodied subsonic turbo-fan aircraft.

variant.question: What are the most frequently used materials in a monocoque or semi-monocoque structure?
What are the three elements of the fuselage structure of a large transport aeroplane?
Refer to annex.  Consider the fuselage cross sections shown in the annex. Place these cross sections in order of decreasing structural suitability for a pressurised cabin.
Flight deck windows are protected against icing with

options.text: Electrical heating supplied by the AC system
Electrical heating supplied by the DC system

variant.question:
Which of these statements regarding cockpit windows are correct or incorrect? 
I. On some aeroplanes the cockpit windows have an additional speed restriction, related to bird impact, when window heating is inoperative. 
II. Cockpit side windows are usually defogged only.

options.text: I is correct, II is correct
I is correct, II is incorrect
I is incorrect, II is incorrect
I is incorrect, II is correct

variant.question: Loads on the cylindrical part of the fuselage during pressurisation are mainly carried by the:
Which one of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The rudder pedals move the nosewheel, but do not move it when the aircraft is airborne.
Rudder pedal moves do not cause nosewheel movement during take-off.
The rudder pedals and steering tiller cause exactly the same movements of the nosewheel.
The rudder pedals cause greater nosewheel movements than the tiller.

variant.question: The manual mode of pressurization in a jet airplane:

options.text: Uses a separate circuit to modulate the opening of the outflow valve.
Acts only on the pressure relief valves.
Only allows to fully open or close the outflow valve.

variant.question: Cabin air for a large aeroplane during flight:

options.text: has a constant oxygen ratio regulated to a preset value.

variant.question: Cabin heating in a large jet transport aeroplane is obtained from ..

options.text: hot air bled from a compressor.
hot air bled from a turbine.

variant.question: Cabin pressurisation is maintained by

options.text: a special blower on the accessory section of the air conditioning system.
regulating the bleed air supply to the cabin.

variant.question: Cabin air for large aeroplanes is usually taken from the ...

options.text: HP compressor and from the LP compressor if necessary.

variant.question: Windscreen heating systems usually:

options.text: cycle ON / OFF to maintain a windscreen temperature between approximately 18° and 35 °C.
consist of warm air from the cabin conditioning system blown across the inner surface of the windscreen.
depend upon the pilot monitoring the windscreen temperature probe for control of the heating system.
are powered from the emergency DC bus.

variant.question: Power for windscreen heating is usually
On large aeroplanes, the fuel tanks can be vented through...

options.text: air intakes on the underside of the wing.
a pressure regulator in the wing tip.
the return lines of the fuel pumps.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 021-42.
What does symbol ‘X’ represent?
The heating facility for the windshield of an aircraft is

options.text: used on a continual basis as it reduces the thermal gradients which adversely affect the useful life of the components.
used only at low altitudes where there is a risk of ice formation.
only used when hot air demisting is insufficient.
harmful to the integrity of the windows in the event of a bird strike.

variant.question: When the air is compressed for pressurization purposes, the percentage oxygen content is

options.text: dependent on the degree of pressurization.

variant.question: An unpressurized aircraft is flying at 12 000 ft. How would be the oxygen flow when required?
With regard to flight crew PBE, which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Above 32 000 ft, or when demanded manually, 100% oxygen is supplied.
100% oxygen is always supplied for flight crew PBE.
When flying above 32 000 ft, 100% oxygen has to be demanded manually.

variant.question: Refer to figure 021-30. Which of the following statements is correct? (Note: all contactors not mentioned are assumed to remain open)

options.text: DC BAT BUS can power the AC ESS BUS via the static inverter if the appropriate contactors are closed.
AC BUS 1 can power DC BUS 2 via the static inverter if the appropriate contactors are closed.
The EMER GEN can only supply the AC ESS BUS via the TRU if the appropriate contactors are closed.
DC BUS 1 can supply AC BUS 1 via TRU 1 if contactor C 5-1 is closed.

variant.question: When is a wing not subject to any tension or compression forces?

options.text: never, the wings are always subject to various forces.
when the aircraft is flying at 1 g.
when the aircraft is still brand new at the factory.
